quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Arrays[/h1]

[b][/b]An [b]Array [/b]is essentially a list of numbered items. 
The items are declared in a comma-separated list and enclosed in square brackets.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="rb" ]items = ["Apple", "Orange", "Banana"][/code]
The code above declares an array named [b]items [/b]containing three strings.

Each item has its own unique [b]index [/b]with the first item at index zero.
To refer to an item, we need to refer to its index: [code format="rb" codeId="1011"]puts items[b][0][/b]
# outputs "Apple"[/code]
You can assign any array element a new value by using its index:[code format="rb" codeId="1020"]items[1] = "Kiwi"[/code]
This will assign the element with index 1 the value "Kiwi"
[note]A negative index is assumed relative to the end of the array. For example, an index of -1 indicates the last element of the array, -2 is the next to last element in the array, and so on.[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
a = [2, 6, 9]
a << 3
a[1] += a[0]
puts a[1]
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Adding Elements[/h1]

An array can contain different types of elements:[code format="rb" codeId="1013"]arr = [5, "Dave", 15.88, false]

puts arr[0] # 5
puts arr[1] # "Dave"
puts arr[-1] # false[/code]
To add new elements to the array, you can use the << operator, which is typed as two less than signs: [code format="rb" codeId="1014"]arr [b]<<[/b] 8

puts arr[/code]
This will add an element with the value 8 to the end of the array.
Alternatively, you can use the [b]push [/b]and [b]insert [/b]methods (we will learn more about methods in the coming module. For now, just remember that a method is code that performs an action).[code format="rb" codeId="1015"]arr.[b]push[/b](8)[/code]
This will add 8 to the end of the array.

The [b]insert [/b]method allows you to insert the element at the desired position: [code format="rb" codeId="1016"]arr.[b]insert[/b](2, 8)[/code]
[note]The code above will insert an element with value 8 at the position with index 2.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to remove the second element of the array.
[!raw!]
arr = [1, 2, 3, 4]
arr.{0}({1})
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Removing Elements[/h1]

Similarly, there are [b]pop [/b]and [b]delete_at [/b]methods available to remove elements from the array.
The [b]pop [/b]method removes the last element of the array.
[b]For example:[/b][code format="rb" codeId="1017"]arr = [1, 2, 3]
arr.[b]pop[/b]
print arr
# [1, 2][/code]
[note]When used to output arrays, the [b]puts [/b]method outputs one element per line, while [b]print[/b] actually outputs brackets and a list of items.[/note]
You can use the [b]delete_at [/b]method to specify the index of the element to be removed:[code format="rb" codeId="1018"]arr = [2, 4, 6, 8]
arr.[b]delete_at(2)
[/b]print arr
# [2, 4, 8][/code]
[note]Remember, the index starts counting at 0. So the third element in the array has the index 2.[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
arr = [4, 7, 5, 2]
arr.delete_at(1)
arr << 3
x = arr[2..3]
puts x[0]
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Array Ranges[/h1]

You can even access a [b]range [/b]within the array using the range operators: [code format="rb" codeId="1019"]nums = [6, 3, 8, 7, 9]
print nums[[b]1..3[/b]]
# [3, 8, 7][/code]
